entry.et: Middle English bitt, from Old English bite act of biting; akin to Old English bītan bite

def.dt: :the biting or cutting edge or part of a tool
:a replaceable part of a compound tool that actually performs the function (as drilling or boring) for which the whole tool is designed
:the jaws of tongs or pincers
:something bitten or held with the teeth:
:the usually steel part of a bridle inserted in the mouth of a horse
:the rimmed mouth end on the stem of a pipe or cigar holder
:something that curbs or restrains
:the part of a key that enters the lock and acts on the bolt and tumblers
:to put a bit in the mouth of (a horse)
:to control as if with a bit
:to form a bit on (a key)

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English bita; akin to Old English bītan bite

def.dt: :a small quantity of food
:a small delicacy
:a small piece or quantity of some material thing
:a small coin
:a unit of value equal to 1/8 of a dollar
:something small or unimportant of its kind: as
:a brief period :while wait a bit longer
:an indefinite usually small degree, extent, or amount a bit of a rascal every bit as powerful
:a small part usually with spoken lines in a theatrical performance
:a usually short theatrical routine
:the aggregate of items, situations, or activities appropriate to a given style, genre, or role rejected the whole bit about love-marriage-motherhood Vance Packard
:somewhat rather the play was a bit dull
:a little more than one wants to endure finds his constant joking a bit much
:by degrees :little by little getting better bit by bit
:totally thoroughly thrilled to bits
:a unit of computer information equivalent to the result of a choice between two alternatives (as yes or no, on or off)
:the physical representation of a bit by an electrical pulse, a magnetized spot, or a hole whose presence or absence indicates data

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English bītan; akin to Old High German bīzan to bite, Latin findere to split

def.dt: :to seize especially with teeth or jaws so as to enter, grip, or wound
:to wound, pierce, or sting especially with a fang or a proboscis
:to cut or pierce with or as if with an edged weapon
:to cause sharp pain or stinging discomfort to
:to take hold of
:to take in :cheat
:to bite or have the habit of biting something
:to cut, pierce, or take hold
:to cause irritation or smarting
:corrode
:to take a bait
:to respond so as to be caught (as by a trick)
:to accept a suggestion or an offer offered them a deal but they wouldn't bite
:to take or maintain a firm hold
:to produce a negative effect the recession began to bite
:to be objectionable or extremely bad in quality :stink suck

dro.drp: bite off more than one can chew

def.dt: :to undertake more than one can handle
:to hold back (as from a reluctance to offend) a remark one would like to make
:to enter with resignation upon a difficult or distressing course of action
:to fall dead especially in battle
:to suffer humiliation or defeat
:to come to an end

dro.drp: bite the hand that feeds one

def.dt: :to injure a benefactor maliciously
:a bit added to an array of bits (as on magnetic tape) to provide parity
:sixpence 2
:of the value of two bits
:cheap or trivial of its kind :petty small-time a two–bit chiseler

entry.et: Middle English, from quite, adjective, quit

def.dt: :wholly completely not quite finished
:to an extreme :positively quite sure often used as an intensifier with a quite a swell guy quite a beauty
:to a considerable extent :rather quite near
:a considerable amount
:many
